did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.unittitle: Farrier Family Papers, 1894-1972
did.physloc: Please note: This collection is in off-site storage and requires 2-3 days notice for retrieval. Please contact Special Collections for more information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from Farrier Family Papers must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech. Since this collection includes legal files, the ability to publish materials may be limited or restricted.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Farrier Family Papers, Ms1974-011, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Farrier Family Papers were donated to Newman Library in 1974.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection is in its original order from the time of donation. Several set of files were rehoused in new boxes during 2011. The finding aid is from existing inventories and research done at the time of donation in 1974. Some descriptive information was added in 2013 and 2014.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Martin P. (1869-1946) and his son, Andrew L. (?-1972) Farrier, lawyers in Pearisburg, Giles County, Virginia. Each was a trial lawyer and each served in the Virginia General Assembly. As a law firm they individually and collectively represented some of the most important industries in Southwest Virginia, including the Norfolk and Western Railway Company, Appalachian Power Company, and several coal and lumber interests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes files from the firm of Williams and Farrier, later Farrier and Farrier. Materials include copies of deeds, title searches, land transactions, estate matters, loan contracts, divorce suits, small claims collection suits, ledgers, and correspondence. Additional details of some files are included in the original inventories, available on request.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is in its original order from the time of its donation. Boxes 1-37, 43 and 44 contain files from the law firms of Williams and Farrier, Farrier and Farrier, and Williams and Farrier and Farrier (the name changed successively over time), as well as some personal papers from the Farrier family. Boxes 38-42 and 45-52 contain ledgers, loose files, and correspondence. Boxes 53 and 54 contain correspondence, arranged alphabetically within six individual letter boxes. Box 55 contains maps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Two series of files from a wooden cabinet. The first set deals mainly with land and estate matters, mostly from the early 1940s. The second set concerns estates. Files are from the office of Pearisburg attorneys, M. P. and A. L. Farrier.

did.unittitle: Various Land Matters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Typed and hand written material concerning land transactions between Welford W. Dowdy and Virginia Dowdy Broadwell, Clarence Sarver, et al, and Everett Scott, Riley Warden and A. B. Allen, Henry Dalton and J.F. Rushbrook, Hallie Porterfield Stower and F. R. Parr and a title to the Mountain View Subdivision in Pearisburg, Va. March 1946-June 1948.

Federal Forest Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Farrier and Farrier negotiate several land transactions between Files County land owners and the USDA Forest Service. Owners are trying to capitalize on the high demand for lumber resulting from its new usage in World War II. December 1935-July 1943.

scopecontent.p: Slight material concerning debts and taxes of the Little Stony Game and Fish Preserve, and a statement declaring M. P. Farrier trustee of the Preserve. See Federal Forest Service file concerning sale of the Preserve. February 1940-October 1944.

Associates Coal and Gas Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: An association of Southwest Virginia businessmen, including M. P. Farrier, F. E. and W. B. Snidow, Martin Williams, and other prominent Giles County men, established for the purpose of exploiting coal and gas deposits in the area. The company does not appear to have done well. File contains mostly handwritten statements concerning debts and assets. June 1925-September 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Substantial correspondence with Bancroft-Whitney Co. concerning the purchases of law books by M. P. and A. L. Farrier. March 1927-October 1946.

Bland County Lumber--Various

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: When the Bland County Lumber Co. went bankrupt some time after 1936, a commissioner was appointed to investigate the company's liabilities and assets. Material in this file consists mainly of M. P. Farrier's handwritten answers to a series of questions put to him by the commissioner. Farrier gives detailed information concerning land holdings and company debts. See related Bland Lumber Co. files (Bland County Lumber Co. v. Mrs. A. A. Strange and Bland Lumber Company Maps).

J. D. Foote

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Present are the receipts showing land taxes paid by J. D. Foote for 1916-1919. Majority of the material consists of deeds showing the extensive land holdings of Foote in Giles County. November 1875-January 1926.

did.unittitle: MPF--Personal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Present are two receipts for a burial blot near Pearisburg, a Christmas card and Valentine card from his wife, and two letters from an acquaintance in Richmond. February 1922-May 1930.

did.unittitle: Giles County--Property Valuations, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: MPF was a member of the county committee which investigated the prospect of establishing a county budget. The committee felt that a budget was unnecessary since the county's revenue was large enough to afford the freedom of action provided by a non-budget system. A detail statement of all assessed real estate and property in Giles County is presented, as well as a statement of yearly county expenditures. Files also contain a copy of the Pearisburg Virginian, dated April 1, 1920, which has a series of articles and editorials concerning a county board for road improvement. October 1918-March 1927.

did.unittitle: General Assembly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Some correspondence, but most material consists of copies of bills MPF wanted presented to the General Assembly. Bills concern: condemnation of private land; collection of taxes and levies; construction and maintenance of division fences; grants of public land; a new charter for the town of Narrows; terms of court for Giles County; sentencing felony convictions; right of land ownership; awarding and dissolving of injunctions; bonding of committees; certificates of acknowledgement; and regulation of judgments. June 1922-April 1928.

did.unittitle: Groseclose Filling Station, March 1927-December 1928.
General Assembly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: MPF was the patron of several bills before the General Assembly on the following subjects: partnerships, sale of estate property and dissolution injunctions. Copies of numerous other bills are included, received by MPF as a member of the General Assembly. February 1932-December 1944.

E. S. Ratcliff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: MPF attempted to aid E. S. Ratcliff in his efforts to obtain full insurance benefits from the U. S. Veterans Bureau owing from his son's death. Mrs. Landona E. Ratcliff was receiving monthly check as a beneficiary of her son. Upon her death, E. S. Ratcliff sought to transfer the benefits to himself acting as administrator of his wife's estate. November 1922.

Sinking Creek Valley Bank

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Incorporation papers for the bank are present as well as several collection cases handled by MPF. In one incident, it appears A. L. Farrier resigned as cashier when his books came up $450 short during an audit. In another, Martin Williams, MPF, and A. L. Farrier were investigated by a state commission to determine their relationship to three lumber companies who borrowed heavily from the bank before folding. July 1912-May 1931.

scopecontent.p: Material found loose at the front of the box. Work by Williams & Farrier or Martin P. Farrier, including deeds, title abstracts, cancelled checks, and a report on improving Mountain Lake. There are also papers concerning the estate of Percy H. Brown.
